Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: Several users report intermittent errors that disrupt normal usage
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: My phone buzzes with another bug report just as I’m about to head out. The app is throwing intermittent errors, and users are getting frustrated. QA is pinging me, asking for a hotfix before the end of the day. I know how important it is to keep the system stable—people rely on this software, and I take pride in being the one who can solve these problems quickly. But then I glance at the clock and remember the ballot measure. The polling place is only open for two more hours, and this vote could change the way our block is zoned. I’ve read up on the issue, and I know my voice matters. As a citizen, I feel a responsibility to show up, to be counted, to help shape the future of my neighborhood. My laptop screen blinks with error logs, while my civic duty tugs at me from across town. I can’t shake the feeling that whichever role I choose, I’ll be letting someone down—my users, my neighbors, or maybe even myself.
